newsitem.title: CANADA: Leaders to discuss China's bid to join WTO.
newsitem.headline: Leaders to discuss China's bid to join WTO.

text.p: China's bid to join the World Trade Organization could give rise to some lively discussion as trade ministers from Japan, the European Union, the United States gather in Toronto this week, Canadian trade officials said on Wednesday.

"The Chinese accession in particular will be on their minds, and also the question of trying to move forward this year with the accession of Russia," said one foreign affairs official who asked not to be named.

"Here, the (Canadian) position has always been that we're eager to move forward with these accessions, but we want to make sure that these countries, in acceeding, are really opening their markets and accepting the disciplines of the World Trade Organization."

The WTO has 130 member countries, with 30 more lining up to join. Trade leaders from the EU, the United States, Japan and Canada are holding a quadrilateral meeting -- dubbed the Quad -- on Thursday and Friday in Toronto which will focus on negotiations and progress at the WTO.
Demands that China improve market access have delayed the country's access to the WTO. There is concern the Quad members could differ on how demanding they should be on China.
But American officials said this week there was hope for a deal with China before this autumn.
Canadian officials said they do not want to divide negotiations with China into trade in goods first and trade in services later.
"We're looking at moving the whole thing forward at once," an official said.
Canada is also expected to defend its policies on cultural protection in bilateral talks with the United States and the European Union.
The EU is considering mounting a WTO challenge of Canada's refusal to let the Dutch firm PolyGram distribute foreign films in Canadda.
And Canada on Wednesday told the WTO it will appeal a panel ruling that taxes it imposes on Canadian editions of U.S. magazines break global trading rules.
At the Quad, the four trade chiefs are also expected to concentrate on opening up financial services markets and liberalizing trade with developing countries.
